title-group.article-title: Multicystic Peritoneal Mesothelioma in an Octogenarian
title-group.subtitle: Diagnosis, Natural History, and Treatment

article-meta.aff: 1University of Massachusetts–Memorial Medical Center, Worcester, MA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Laura A. Lambert, Division of Surgical Oncology, University of Massachusetts–Memorial Medical Center, Swift House, 119 Belmont Street, Worcester, MA 01605, USA Email: laura.lambert@umassmemorial.org

abstract.p: Multicystic peritoneal mesothelioma (MCPM) is a rare cystic proliferation most often seen in women of reproductive age with a history of prior abdominal surgery. This is a case report of an 83-year-old woman diagnosed with MCPM during an exploratory laparotomy for presumed peritoneal carcinomatosis from colon cancer. After complete removal of all visible MCPM, the patient remains free of both colon cancer and MCPM. This article reviews the literature with regards to the pathology, natural history, risk of malignant transformation, and current options for management of MCPM, including cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Multicystic peritoneal mesothelioma (MCPM) is a rare condition characterized by the proliferation of mesothelial cell-lined intra-abdominal cysts. It was first described by Plaut1 in 1928. Since then, approximately 140 cases of MCPM have been reported in the literature with the vast majority occurring in women of reproductive age.2,3 Despite being considered a benign condition, recurrences are common and advanced disease can be life-threatening. In addition, reports of transformation to malignant peritoneal mesothelioma (MPM) exist.4 Because of the rarity of this disease, there is little data to guide clinical management. We report the finding of MCPM in an 83-year-old woman with a history of stage II colon cancer and review the literature with regards to the pathology, natural history, risk of malignant transformation, and current options for management.

sec.title: Case Presentation
sec.p: The patient is an 83-year-old woman with no prior surgical history and a past medical history significant for asthma and hypertension. She presented to medical attention with mild anemia and heme-occult positive stool. Colonoscopy identified a fungating mass at the hepatic flexure. A right hemicolectomy was performed. The final pathology demonstrated a stage II (T4b, N0) invasive adenocarcinoma of the proximal transverse colon. Fifteen months after surgery, surveillance computed tomography (CT) scan revealed multiple low attenuation lesions within the peritoneal cavity (Figure 1A). Serum carcinogen embryonic antigen (CEA) was normal. Repeat CT scan 3 months later demonstrated increasing size of some of the peritoneal lesions (Figure 1B). CT-guided fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy of 2 of the lesions showed acellular serous fluid. The case was reviewed by the Gastrointestinal Multidisciplinary Tumor Board. Exploratory laparotomy and cytoreduction was recommended because of the progression of these lesions. At the time of surgery, there were more than 20 fluid-filled, thin-walled cysts scattered throughout the peritoneal cavity ranging in size from 1 to 6 cm in diameter (Figure 2). The cysts were present on the peritoneal lining of the abdominal wall, the antimesenteric sides of the small bowel, and on the peritoneum overlying the bowel mesentery. Cysts were also identified on the surface of the liver and on the peritoneum overlying the bladder. All the cysts were removed at the time of surgery and sent for pathologic examination. The patient’s postoperative course was unremarkable. Final pathology demonstrated cysts lined by bland mesothelial cells, without hemorrhage, necrosis, or mitosis (Figure 3). Cytokeratin 5/6 and calretinin immunostains were diffusely positive (Figure 4). Both the cytologic features and immunohistochemical profiles were consistent with MCPM.

caption.p: Computed tomography (CT) scan images of 83-year-old woman with multicystic peritoneal mesothelioma (MCPM)

A, Initial CT scan showing largest intraperitoneal lesion in right lower quadrant (arrow). B, Follow-up CT scan 3 months later showing interval increase in size of intraperitoneal lesion in right lower quadrant (arrow).
A, Representative cyst on small bowel at time of surgery. B, Peritoneal cyst on pedicle.

A, Gross images of peritoneal cysts. B, Low-power microscopic image showing multiloculated cysts lined by cuboidal cells. C (inset), Low-power microscopic image showing cyst filled with clear serous fluid.
High-powered histologic preparations of cells lining peritoneal cyst wall
A, Immunostaining for CK5/6. B, Immunostaining for calretinin.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: MCPM is a rare, non-neoplastic, condition characterized by the proliferation of mesothelial cell-lined intra-abdominal cysts. Other synonyms used to describe this condition include “multilocular peritoneal inclusion cysts” and “benign cystic mesothelioma.” To date, at least 140 cases of MCPM have been reported with the vast majority occurring in women of childbearing age.2 Prior to this case report, the oldest patient reported to have MCPM was a 79-year-old woman who presented with tiredness, decreased appetite, and weight loss and was found to have a large cystic mass with calcification in the left upper quadrant.5 The mass was described to be partially cystic with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis and with gland-forming cells that were positive for cytokeratin. The cytokeratins were not further specified and the gland formation argues against a diagnosis of MCPM. Only 24 cases of MCPM have been reported in male patients6-10 and 5 cases have been reported in pediatric patients (range 11 months to 14 years).11-15 A previous report by Katsube et al16 found that 9 out of 10 patients were white and that there was no relationship between MCPM and parity. Unlike MPM, there is no known association between MCPM and exposure to asbestos.17,18

Like the current case, the majority of reported cases were found incidentally. However, MCPM can be symptomatic. The most common presenting signs and symptoms are abdominal discomfort, dysuria, and an abdominal or pelvic mass leading to distension or feeling of fullness.3,19 Less common presenting symptoms include dysfunctional uterine bleeding and dyspareunia.19 A definitive preoperative diagnosis of MPM is difficult to establish through imaging and FNA, and exploratory laparoscopy or laparotomy is usually necessary to definitively diagnose MCPM.16 Findings at the time of surgery usually include multiple cysts varying in size from a few millimeters up to 20 cm in diameter.19 These cysts are typically filled with clear, serous fluid; however, they can occasionally contain a more gelatinous translucent substance.20 Histologically, the cysts are lined by a single layer of cytologically bland cuboidal cells sometimes overlying a spindled stroma.16,21 A panel of immunohistochemical staining is usually performed for definitive diagnosis. The lining cells are consistently positive for calretinin, cytokeratin 5/6, and Wilm’s tumor 1/antigen, confirming their mesothelial origin.3,22 Conversely, the cells are negative for the epithelial cell markers CEA, B72.3, and Ber-Ep4.22 Lack of immunoreactivity for endothelial cell markers such as FVIII, CD31, and CD34 is also helpful in differentiating this lesion from cystic lymphangioma.23 A minority of cases are reported to be immunoreactive for estrogen and/or progesterone receptors, leading some to suggest a potential role for hormonal therapy as a treatment option.3

Currently, the precise pathogenesis and etiology of MCPM remains undetermined.15,20 The diversity of the names for this lesion reflects the uncertainty of its biological behavior and the reluctance of pathologists to use the term mesothelioma to avoid misinterpretation by both clinicians and patients. Some authors consider MCPM to be a hyperplastic or reactive process citing its tendency to occur in patients with history of abdominal surgery, inflammatory processes, or endometriosis.24,25 Others argue that MCPM is indeed a neoplastic process, citing its high rate of recurrence and rare, but notable, incidence of malignant transformation.4,23,26 Although, 3 cases of MCPM-associated mortality are reported in literature, only one was due to a confirmed malignant transformation.4,26,27 This case occurred in an adult female patient who succumbed to an MPM arising from a benign cyst 10 years after her initial diagnosis of MCPM. During that time she underwent 6 debulking laparotomies.4

Current recommended treatment for MCPM is complete surgical resection of the intra-abdominal cysts. Completeness of the resection is the best prognostic factor for disease-free survival.19 Reported rates of recurrence range from 41.7% to 50.0%, with an average time to recurrence of 2 to 3 years.3,16,19 Some authors advocate the use of intraperitoneal chemotherapy, often combined with hyperthermia (HIPEC), at the time of cytoreductive surgery (CRS) to decrease the risk of recurrence.4,22,23 Between 1999 and 2008, 4 case series of CRS and HIPEC in the management of MCPM have been published (Table 1).22,23,28,29 Although the individual series have small numbers of patients (cumulative total = 12), the overall rate of recurrence was only 16.7% (n = 2) with an average disease-free survival of 35 months. One patient recurred in the setting of malignant transformation. The other underwent a second CRS and HIPEC and remained disease-free at 25 months of follow-up.22 Based on these reports, and given recent improvements in the safety and efficacy of CRS and HIPEC, early referral to a peritoneal surface malignancy program should be considered for patients with MCPM.

caption.p: Cytoreductive Surgery and Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy for Multicystic Peritoneal Mesothelioma

fn.label: a
fn.p: One patient required second hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC).

fn.label: b
fn.p: Recurrence occurred in setting of malignant transformation.
